topic.title: Private zeronet site. Can it be hidden forever?
topic.body:
Imagine that I made a zeronet site and share with the peers only under the local network. 

As long as I don't disclose the link to the peers outside, will it be kept hidden forever even though the peers in the local network are open to the internet?

topic.title: Hello ZeroNet needs flagging feature on its right pane seriously.
topic.body:
One would probably write a comment offline, and it could be updated or published a day or a week later. Then, that comment will pop up in the middle of the piles of articles where people even don't notice it's there.

Every article and comment data structure should be equipped with `read` flag, so that `unread` articles could be filtered by the user who set flags.

Or, `most recently updated (not most recently uploaded/posted) articles` feature will also do the job

[My ZeroMe](http://127.0.0.1:43110/Me.ZeroNetwork.bit/?Profile/1SunAWK2VUT9GQK32MpwRfFPVgcBSJN9a/16dEowtNbV89NxPcDrAKkmnuXtiJVoVcDm/leftside@zeroid.bit).

topic.title: Keeping comments when the original post was removed by the author.
topic.body:
https://github.com/HelloZeroNet/ZeroTalk/issues/63

Some users delete their posts without showing any respect to the commenters' efforts, so that no matter how many comments were attached all of them disappear too.

So people become reluctant to comment any more so that the ZeroNet community's falling down.

Allow the topic creator to choose what to remove among title, body and author ID.
In case the bulletin board doesn't allow anonymous posting, when he selects 'remove author ID' show him the msg saying 'Removing author ID will remove the title and the body together and they will not be recovered.' If click 'yes', remove all 3 items, but still remains comments under the topic.

(Empty title and body will be replaced with the msg [removed]. Then anyhow people still can read the comments in it)

http://127.0.0.1:43110/Me.ZeroNetwork.bit/?Profile/1SunAWK2VUT9GQK32MpwRfFPVgcBSJN9a/16dEowtNbV89NxPcDrAKkmnuXtiJVoVcDm/leftside@zeroid.bit

topic.title: RE: Is war justified for any reasons?
topic.body:
> swordfish: [I want to know your opinions on this](http://127.0.0.1:43110/Talk.ZeroNetwork.bit/?Topic:1520480628_19k3r2zgWTUszFvHSBBrxDWzEt83VqY7BA)

100% of wars on earth involve killing innocent people. 

And the idea which is believed to be a kind of justification in solving certain problems used to be brought up repeatedly through out the human history. That means, it didn't solve the problem in fact. Rather, the problems have been growing worse and worse. 

What does it mean? War can't be justified. It's just like that a boy is losing his shoes again and again whenever his mom buys him new ones. He doesn't deserve *WEARING SHOES*. 

And most wars committed by the countries of the power were not done in the way the war supporters desired. Rather, they were done for the profit of a small group of elites. The elites persuade people to support their plan to run a war business. And the idiot people support them. 

They lose their shoes, and their children lose again, and again. 

This globe is a kind of a laboratory. Human being has experimented thousands of times in wars, politics, economies and religions. And it turned out those experiments have been all failed! And they lost the shoes again! What a ridiculous situation. 

Humans-rule-humans system has absolutely failed.

No more experiments are justified. 

[sos4sos@riseup.net 2018-03-08 13-25-49](http://127.0.0.1:43110/Me.ZeroNetwork.bit/?Profile/1SunAWK2VUT9GQK32MpwRfFPVgcBSJN9a/16dEowtNbV89NxPcDrAKkmnuXtiJVoVcDm/leftside@zeroid.bit)

topic.title: RE: Translations Needed for Important Zites (Korean Translation)
topic.body:
Response to [Translations Needed for Important Zites](http://127.0.0.1:43110/Talk.ZeroNetwork.bit/?Topic:1520667301_12gAes6NzDS9E2q6Q1UXrpUdbPS6nvuBPu).

__I translated the word list but for the better quality detailed description of the usage of each word is desired.__

Important Zites : 중요 자이트. (사이트 in case of **Sites**)
Categories : 카테고리
All : 전체
Search Engine : 검색엔진
Social Network / Platform : SNS/플렛폼
Gaming : 게임
Blog / Personal : 블로그 / 개인
File Sharing / Streaming : 파일공유 / 스트리밍
News / Info : 뉴스 / 정보
Productivity / Tools : 생산성 / 유틸
Merger Zite : 머져 자이트(사이트) OR 통합 자이트 // Because we don't have a consensus on the glossaries for ZeroNet for Korean language, this translation would be modified in the future.
Other : 기타
Search Other Zites : 타 자이트 검색
Edit : 수정(편집)
Delete : 삭제
Show Merger Zites : 머져(통합) 자이트 보기
Bookmark : 북마크
Unbookmark : 북마크 해제
Home : 홈
My Zites : 내 자이트
My Bookmarks : 내 북마크
Settings : 설정
Switch User : 사용자 변환
Login : 로그인 
Add Zite : 자이트 추가
Add New Zite : 새 자이트 추가
Edit Zite : 자이트 수정
Title : 제목
Zite Address (Not .bit Address) : 자이트 주소 (.bit 주소 아님)
Zite .bit Domain (if exists) : 자이트 .bit 도메인 (있다면)
Zite Creator / Maintainer : 자이트 제작자 / 관리자
Description : 설명
Category : 카테고리 
Choose Your Option : 옵션을 선택하세요
Language(s) : 언어
Enter Tags : 태그 입력
Tags : 태그
NSFW : 19금
Press Enter to Add Tag : 태그를 추가하려면 엔터치세요.
Merger-Supported (more info in sidebar, or below on mobile) : 머져(통합)-지원 (추가 정보는 사이드바 참고, 혹은 모바일의 경우 하단에)
Merger Category Name : 머져(통합) 카테고리 명칭
Submit : 입력완료
Required : 필요
Search My Bookmarks : 내 북마크 검색
Search My Zites : 내 자이트 검색
Search Zites : 자이트 검색
Search In ... Category : ... 카테고리 검색
Uploaded by ... : 작성자: ...
Published by ... : 발행자: ...
File Size : 파일 크기
Date Uploaded : 작성 날짜시간
Date Updated : 업데이트 날짜시간
Date Published : 발행 날짜시간
Search [zite name] : 검색 [사이트 이름]
[zite name] Clones : [자이트 이름] 클론

Notes:

    NSFW means "Not Safe For Work", it's used for porn/adult zites.
    For tags, you press enter - I put this line to translate because of the tags part: "Press Enter to Add Tag".
    The asterisks are to say that they are required before you can submit (because these phrases are used on the Add Zite and Edit zite pages).

[sos4sos@riseup.net](http://127.0.0.1:43110/Me.ZeroNetwork.bit/?Profile/1SunAWK2VUT9GQK32MpwRfFPVgcBSJN9a/16dEowtNbV89NxPcDrAKkmnuXtiJVoVcDm/leftside@zeroid.bit) 2018-03-10

topic.title: What is auth_address in users.json and in users_archive.json and certs_*.json?
topic.body:
@nofish called the 2nd value of the comma separated data "@9,17UkpN" in `users_archive.json` **"auth_address"** in [this post](http://127.0.0.1:43110/Talk.ZeroNetwork.bit/?Topic:1519994634_13E6xCFLmbGYCNAPrKd3m5o6gTgnzMW4rd). 

* ```nofish ━ on Mar 03, 2018 The users_archive.json is introduced the stripped the data to reduce the site's size. @9,17UkpN means the full data is in the optional file data/certs_9.json and the auth_address starts with 17UkpN. (If you want to search user by public address)```

Yes, he was right. I could find it in certs_*.json. 

But when I tried to find the first 6 characters of auth_address value in `users.json` under the /data/ folder, it just failed. Why not? Any one of those auth_address values could be found anywhere under /data/ folder.

topic.title: Is there any body who seriously tested no-internet local peer data exchange among the local networking PCs?
topic.body:
I tested 3 various linux PCs + 1 Windows7 + 1 android phone under the same AP.
It doesn't work reliably. It's totally unpredictable. 

What do u think?

**PC#1**
* ARMBIAN 5.38 stable Ubuntu 16.04.5 LTS 3.4.113-sun8i
* Wifi 192.168.0.8
* https://github.com/HelloZeroNet/ZeroNet/archive/master.tar.gz
* Installed yesterday
* Local only mode start: `$ python2 zeronet.py --tor disable --ui_ip 192.168.0.8;`

**PC#2**
* ** `ARMBIAN 5.38 stable Debian GNU/Linux 9 (stretch) 4.14.14-sunxi` **
* Wifi 192.168.0.9
* https://github.com/HelloZeroNet/ZeroNet/archive/master.tar.gz
* Installed yesterday
* Local only mode start: `$ python2 zeronet.py --tor disable; --ui_ip 192.168.0.9`

**PC#3**
* Windows7
* Wifi 192.168.0.2
* https://github.com/HelloZeroNet/ZeroNet-win/archive/dist/ZeroNet-win.zip
* Installed 6 months ago and non-updated. (Tried online update but seems not update, so that I may need to fresh-install again)
* Local only mode start: `$ ZeroNet --ui_ip 192.168.0.2;`

**PC#4**
* UBUNTU 16.04.5 LTS (Xenial Xerus)
* Wifi 192.168.0.55
* https://github.com/HelloZeroNet/ZeroBundle/raw/master/dist/ZeroBundle-linux64.tar.gz
* Installed 6 months ago and continuously updated.
* Local only mode start: `$ ./ZeroNet.sh --tor disable;` (my main PC)

**PC#5**
* Android phone

**PC#6**
* Android phone

**My comments continues here: http://127.0.0.1:43110/Me.ZeroNetwork.bit/?Post/1SunAWK2VUT9GQK32MpwRfFPVgcBSJN9a/16dEowtNbV89NxPcDrAKkmnuXtiJVoVcDm/1534034776 -- 2018-08-15_12-29-59(+0900KST)**

topic.title: $6 trillion of local government debt may be lurking under the surface in China: S&P
topic.body:
[$6 trillion of local government debt may be lurking under the surface in China: S&P](https://www.reddit.com/r/investing/comments/9omd2t/6_trillion_of_local_government_debt_may_be/)

The actual level of off-balance-sheet Chinese local government debt could be several times more than what is publicly disclosed and range as high as 30 trillion yuan to 40 trillion yuan, or about $4.34 trillion to $5.78 trillion, S&P Global Ratings analysts say in a report.

"That's a debt iceberg with titanic credit risks," the analysts say, estimating that the ratio of all government debt to GDP was 60 percent last year.

As a result, S&P Global Ratings expects authorities will allow more defaults in local government financing vehicles.

https://www.cnbc.com/2018/10/16/china-hidden-local-government-debt-could-be-6-trillion-sp.html

topic.title: Paralysis desease epidemic among kids in USA.
topic.body:
https://abcnews.go.com/Health/62-cases-afm-confirmed-22-states-cdc/story?id=58532330

There are now 62 confirmed reports of acute flaccid myelitis, or AFM, an illness similar to polio, across 22 states in the U.S., according to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.

As of Sept. 20, the CDC had confirmed 38 cases in 16 states, which aren't required to report AFM cases to the CDC.

This year's numbers are similar to 2016 and 2014. Since 2014, 386 cases have been confirmed, the CDC said on Tuesday. Currently, 127 patients are under investigation. The average age of those afflicted is 4, and 90 percent of those with AFM are 18 or younger.

topic.title: What's New in Enigmail v2.0?
topic.body:
Welcome to the new Enigmail version 2.0!

The release contains a lot of new and changed features. Please take a minute to find out what's new:
Encrypting the Message Subject

We developed a new method that moves the email subject into the encrypted message, and replaces the visible subject with "Encrypted Message". Once such a message is decrypted, the original subject is replaced automatically. Hiding the subject is on by default; there is a preference to turn it off if you don't like it. (Note: this feature requires the message to be sent with PGP/MIME.)
Changed behavior of Encrypt and Sign Buttons

The Encrypt and Sign buttons in the message composer window now work for both the OpenPGP and S/MIME protocols. If both algorithms are possible, then Enigmail will try to prefer the one for which all keys are available.
Support for Autocrypt

Enigmail now supports Autocrypt, a new standard to distribute keys as part of sent messages. Enigmail automatically imports keys from Autocrypt-compliant messages, such that over time more and more emails can be encrypted.
New p≡p Junior Mode (Pretty Easy Privacy)

Enigmail now contains a p≡p Junior Mode. The p≡p Junior Mode allows you to use OpenPGP encryption as transparently as possible; you don't need to care for key management and synchronization of keys between devices anymore.

Please visit [our documentation](https://enigmail.net/home/docu.php) for help on using Enigmail.

topic.title: ls -f is 16 times faster than ls -1 in case of 1Ms files in a directory.
topic.body:
Recently I've been downloading huge forums. As a result came to deal with millions of files with shell commands.
Found out that `ls -1` or `ls` in nature performs sorting before giving out the result to the user. But `ls -f` does not. 
This is useful for me to measure the downloading speed per a post by `ls -f | wc -l` with 30s intervals.
Is there any other quicker method to perform counting the number of files in a directory?

topic.title: People, do u let ur browser scratch your precious SSD?
topic.body:
I changed every cache data to be written on RAM, not on SSD. 

This sometimes annoys me that I have to remove some huge cache data for youtube videos which I kept opened after watching in other tabs by closing the window and restore the window again (but still keeping background tabs hibernated via a firefox addon), or simply quit firefox and restart firefox again. 

But this gives me a very silent environment regarding SSD wearleveling.

$ sudo iotop; -> Calm and peaceful. 

In regard with Zeronet, plz put them in the PC with HDD, not SSD. Or you may simply install them on /dev/shm or /tmp RAM drive while temporarily performing backup to SSD or HDD.

topic.title: Do you guys also have the concept of year-end tax refund for salary men and women?
topic.body:
In Korea, every new year there's a huge struggling among salary men and women to prepare documents and receipts to refund some parts of the tax they paid last year. 

Company takes some of the salary of its employees according to the calculation table which National Tax Service made for various jobs and salary levels, so that the company pays the income tax of the employees in advance.

But there're a lot of discounts if the employees submit various groups of receipts they spent last year to the government, most times via their company or sometimes via themselves in http://hometax.go.kr. 

For example, if u purchased items or paid for services with ur credit card more than $300, they subtract such an amount from the denominator or the reference income which is the reference value to calculate the tax. Or all the amount paid for his own education or his children's education are subtracted no matter how much it is, etc. It''s a bit complicated for normal people, so the related web sites and forums suffer a sudden jam by those people around every year-end. 

Every year the calculation table changes in ratios for each criteria, people's spending pattern changes according to it. For example discount rates between the credit card and debit card change and that affects the credit card companies' income from the transaction commissions while the merchandisers get benefits by saving the credit card commission, etc. 

Government is reducing discount ratio of the credit card while increasing debit card and cash with government registered card which doesn't require any commission or paper receipt to keep in a physical storage, which also reduces the time spent in organizing and converting into the digital data.

Anyway, by those efforts, most times u get refunded from $100 to $1000 or more every year from the government. If u missed submitting those documents or failed to spend money in a smart way, u will get nothing or sometimes will have to pay more tax if company used to take too small amount from ur salary for the prepaying tax last year. 

How'bout other countries?

topic.title: Introduction of SPAMMABILITY SCORE to fight spammers.
topic.body:
Further discussion : [Introduction of CAPTCHA for the new users.](../Talk.ZeroNetwork.bit/?Topic:1549631999_16dEowtNbV89NxPcDrAKkmnuXtiJVoVcDm/Introduction+of+CAPTCHA+for+the+new+users#comment_91_14mSHL2TBcqcLNcfpmg5jyGVS9RZia3FiX)

How to calculate SPAMMABILITY SCORE :

`echo "scale=4; $(cat spam.txt | sed 's/[ \.,]/\n/g' | wc -l) / $(cat spam.txt | sed 's/[ \.,]/\n/g' | sort | uniq | wc -l)" | bc`

Just put the spam text into `spam.txt` and copy the above command line and paste into your bash terminal. And run.

This gives:
206/33 = 6.24 for the previous shit-guy's comment [1].
342/16 = 21.38 for the previous-previous one [2].

That is, the previous-previous one is more spammable than the previous one. 

My normal comment [3]'s **SPAMMABILITY SCORE** is 146/81 = 1.8

Very low compared to those of the shit-guy's.

This works like a charm~!

But, this will not work forever if they notice this and change the strategy.

Plz refer to some [discussion](../Me.ZeroNetwork.bit/?Post/12h51ug6CcntU2aiBjhP8Ns2e5VypbWWtv/1NWh3WAty57FH8at1WtrZigMrdhrDkuPzh/1549529668) on this matter.

topic.title: SPAM ISSUE: DDoS kind of attacks to Zeronet might be possible in the near future.
topic.body:
By making millions of IDs for a period of several days or weeks without being noticed, they could post garbage data all at once or do something else in any kind of malicious manners. Not only in ZeroTalk or ZeroMe, but also in the minor sites the news feed of which is not shown in the ZeroHello front page. 

This can fill the entire disk space of the user's HDD or hit the limit of the disk space which Zeronet configured in order to protect the critical system processes to make use of some disk space, though  still disabling the user's zeronet since it can't write any more data to the disk. In addition, plz refer to [People, do u let ur browser scratch your precious SSD?](../Talk.ZeroNetwork.bit/?Topic:1548210080_16dEowtNbV89NxPcDrAKkmnuXtiJVoVcDm) for the users with SSD or NAND flash memories of smart phones.

Plz check [Introduction of SPAMMABILITY SCORE to fight spammers.](../Talk.ZeroNetwork.bit/?Topic:1549554952_16dEowtNbV89NxPcDrAKkmnuXtiJVoVcDm) regarding the uprising of the spammers last night. Also read [Introduction of CAPTCHA for the new users.](../Talk.ZeroNetwork.bit/?Topic:1549631999_16dEowtNbV89NxPcDrAKkmnuXtiJVoVcDm)

topic.title: Introduction of CAPTCHA for the new users.
topic.body:
> [trenta3](#comment_91_14mSHL2TBcqcLNcfpmg5jyGVS9RZia3FiX): @leftside Does this just count words / unique words? [...]

Plz refer to the original discussion in here: [Introduction of SPAMMABILITY SCORE to fight spammers](../Talk.ZeroNetwork.bit/?Topic:1549554952_16dEowtNbV89NxPcDrAKkmnuXtiJVoVcDm) and [SPAM ISSUE: DDoS kind of attacks to Zeronet might be possible in the near future](../Talk.ZeroNetwork.bit/?Topic:1549585526_16dEowtNbV89NxPcDrAKkmnuXtiJVoVcDm/SPAM+ISSUE+DDoS+kind+of+attacks+to+Zeronet+might+be+possible+in+the+near+future).

@trenta3, making any new users obligatory to obtain a certain key of a random captcha (from captcha-key pair database) before granting him the right to post will help the situation far better. 

The problem is where to save such flags for each user and how to apply captcha to the user. 

My suggestion is using a command line bot on the site creator's PC. 

The bot will generate a new HTML page which is paired to a certain user. 

If the user without a paired key for that unique HTML page for him tries to post or vote in the site, in the beginning his post will be uploaded to the peers' PCs. But the bot will detect this activity and will mention this user while replying him with the link to the captcha which is generated for him as mentioned above. Of course the bot has to keep track of the pairs of the users and the captcha links in the local PC in a kind of filename `captcha.txt`.

(**UPDATE** : The user will never be able to write anything on the target site without having a proper key of the captcha from the separate captcha site in advance as mentioned in my comments below. 2019-02-11 18:49:44+0900)

It'd be good if the site has a link titled "New users, signup first!" on the top of the front page so that every answer of the new users gathers in that post in the comment section.

And, unless he posts the proper answer to the linked page of the captcha which was given by the bot in the previous reply, any activities of this user will be banned by the bot's deletion and by the bot's editing `data/users/content.json` to make `max_size` property of the very user to set to ZERO. The bot will sign/publish by itself the change of `content.json` so that it affects soon.

The way how the new user answers the CAPTCHA must have been described in the previous reply to the user such as: "To enable your account, click [reply] button on the right side of my ID [zerobot] and input the correct answer for your CAPTCHA, and click [Submit comment]."

As soon as the user makes reply to the bot, the bot checks the answer and decides to grant him the right to post or not. And the bot will set flag on this user in `captcha.txt`. If not correct answer, the bot will give him a few more chances to try. When this process ends, the HTML page for the user will be deleted on the bot's PC and sign/publish the site again to make the change effective to everybody.

This captcha method also can be used for every renewal or raising limit of the capacity of posting instead of the current manual raising by the site creator.

PS: Where on earth @blurhy has gone??? He's a specialist on this field! Where's @binchan? 
I don't want to code this bot with my clumsy hands! :(

**UPDATE**
More upgraded features are introduced in my comments below. 2019-02-09_01-31-05+0900

**UPDATE**
This method is totally **decentralized CAPTCHA** independent from any clearnet things by the way. Even independent from so called _decentralized ID providers_ in zeronet. 2019-02-09_10-51-40+0900

topic.title: SUGGESTION: http://127.0.0.1:43110/zeronet.io/1TaLkFrMwvbNsooF4ioKAY9EuxTBTjipT
topic.body:
It's a regret that @nofish hasn't put the landmark in ZeroNet URL format.
So I suggest @nofish and other zeronet Jedi(s) to make the upgraded zeronet URL system.

Put "zeronet.io" in every URL of zeronet sites:

`http://127.0.0.1:43110/zeronet.io/1TaLkFrMwvbNsooF4ioKAY9EuxTBTjipT`
becomes the same as `http://127.0.0.1:43110/1TaLkFrMwvbNsooF4ioKAY9EuxTBTjipT`.

`zeronet.io` is not a **MUST** part of the URL but optional. 
That is, every other existing URLs will still work fine even after applying this upgrade, but it will still work even with `zeronet.io` is inserted in the middle.

If possible, it'd be better if zeronet itself automatically converted every exiting URL into `...43110/zeronet.io/...` just to be shown in the browser not to be converted in database level so that even though any time any user copies URLs of any moment in zeronet they would get `...43110/zeronet.io...` URLs for reference.

If needed, we can put `0net.io` or something as cadidates as well. You can put `visit_zeronet.io_to_download_zeronet_server_client` as well! lol.
#Or you can just open the first level path to anything whatever they type!
Like, "[http://127.0.0.1:43110/**This_is_how_to_kill_the_mocking_bird**/16J4mEgR5aqerfzGy2WctNV3onPQUgF2E5/upload/real%20size%20of%20countries%20map%206wncgOBGIC8.jpg](http://127.0.0.1:43110/16J4mEgR5aqerfzGy2WctNV3onPQUgF2E5/upload/real%20size%20of%20countries%20map%206wncgOBGIC8.jpg)". lol.

**What's the benefit?**

By adding this feature in zeronet URL formet, even though u put zeronet URL in the clearnet, people can still find a hint where to go with zeronet URL. At the moment, if u put zeronet URL anywhere in the world, most people will think it's just a crab and some will regard it just a stupid newbie's mistake putting his home local PC's server URL in the public. 

But if u put `zeronet.io`, they will definitely notice it and will try to figure out what `zeronet.io` is. (Of course, if it's zeronet`.net` it would attract people's interest more easily anyway. -- by [leftside](../1Gtubs5zzkhkVAxiEyZuYTJMWSpJ1qY22s/?Post:16:SUGGESTION:+http://127.0.0.1:43110/zeronet.io/1TaLkFrMwvbNsooF4ioKAY9EuxTBTjipT) sos4sos@riseup.net // 2019-02-12 10:27:35+0900

PS: Furthermore we also need to make the design http://zeronet.io more intuitive.

# UPDATE

Of course this can be bypassed by attaching the phrase in the tail of the URL without modifying any source code etc like:http://127.0.0.1:43110/Talk.ZeroNetwork.bit/?This_is_how_to_kill_the_mocking_bird.

It means, just make every zeronet URL in zeronet to be printed in HTML as '[original URL]?visit_zero.io_and_install_zeronet' will suffice.
As already mentioned, there's no need to convert every single URL in database or users.json but just beautify the screen HTML expression.

topic.title: UPGRADE INFO: ZeroBlog derivatives, how to set each page title with its post subject.
topic.body:
Original discussion: [ Every site owner! Plz make page title out of its subject! #72 ](https://github.com/HelloZeroNet/ZeroTalk/issues/72)

Edit all.js. 
Find 'title_hash = post.title.replace' string. 
Insert the following line under the above found line:
`Page.cmd("wrapperSetTitle", post.title + " - Leftside_s Blog");`
Save.
Sign & publish your site/blog.
Open any post in ur site/blog.
Ctrl-F5. 
Done.

Refer to [sample blog of mine.](../1Gtubs5zzkhkVAxiEyZuYTJMWSpJ1qY22s/?Post:6)

topic.body:
I told u guys. These firefox developers might be bribed by M$, Apple or Google secretly.
These malicious assholes have moved to stupid Firefox Quantum version by abandoning the most valuable addons such as session manager or tab manager or something.

### How to solve with the improvised method ###

### Tor-browser solved this bug in version 8.0.9 ##
https://blog.torproject.org/new-release-tor-browser-809#comments 
## Recover your about:config setting from false to true with 'xpinstall.signatures.required' as long as you're a tor-browser user not a regular firefox browser user. -- 2019-05-07 12:37:25+0900

### Solution for regular firefox browser
[Please refer to @filips's comment below](http://127.0.0.1:43110/Talk.ZeroNetwork.bit/?Topic:1556958282_16dEowtNbV89NxPcDrAKkmnuXtiJVoVcDm/Firefox+is+seriously+disturbed+in+purpose+Most+addons+have+gone+disabled#comment_17_1LFu1BTScmY82HHtg3TY2jAuSrCYNsQWEY) -- 2019-05-08 08:22:50+0900
This was fixed in version 66.0.4. See [release notes](https://www.mozilla.org/en-US/firefox/66.0.4/releasenotes/) for details.
In case your addons are still disabled (even in new version), try to disable & enable them. If they still not work, try to re-download them.
**Solution for old (unsupported) versions**
You need to manually download and install new certificate into Firefox. See [this Reddit topic](https://www.reddit.com/r/firefox/comments/bkspmk/addons_fix_for_5602_older/) for details.

If you want it real secure, so even the feds would have a hard time, you can do it the way I suggested or yeah, you could check to key, but people that download the html file would probably be able to see the contents...

`data.json` itself will be encrypted with the group private key at the time of posting to local 127.0.0.1, so that no chance to be eavesdropped by someone. 

While updating among the open internet, data.json would be found to have encrypted subjects, bodies, authors, etc.

Only appointed personnel could decrypt the contents. 

All these procedures could be done by command line PGP, and just copy & paste to the text box of the site. 
But it would be great if ZeroTalk-like sites could provide these with only one mouse click of checkbox, right?

1537594142_1CthCNo2eADyWkShCTBTVKGHy3WNX.body:
> [thornranger](#comment_2_1CthCNo2eADyWkShCTBTVKGHy3WNXcj6Fh): /usr/bin/avconv -y -i ~/$(cat read1)

`-i ~/$(cat read1)` makes an error msg `read1: File name too long` since avconv regards $(cat read1) as a single filename including '\n's for each line as a whole.
`$ find` without `-maxdepth 1` option  could lead to avconv error like `could not find the folder ***/***/` if there's *partialfilename.mp3 in a subfolder.

@thornranger , If your recently downloaded .mp3's are to be located in a restricted folder, it's OK without `-maxdepth 1` option. But if u can choose the folder to be downloaded, why do you need to limit the timestamps of the .mp3's? Every .mp3 in the very folder is the one which needs to be converted and moved to the other folder, isn't it?

> [thornranger](#comment_9_1CthCNo2eADyWkShCTBTVKGHy3WNXcj6Fh): openssl enc -k yourpasswordhere

That command has a problem revealing passphrase to somewhere. Why don't u use `$ gpg --encrypt [filename]` which doesn't reveal any password?

> [thornranger](#comment_11_1CthCNo2eADyWkShCTBTVKGHy3WNXcj6Fh): man -Tpdf man >man.pdf

> [trenta3](#comment_38_14mSHL2TBcqcLNcfpmg5jyGVS9RZia3FiX):  

I think this can be achieved by making the same use of ZeroHello's user-focus oriented screen updating mechanism. Based on the user's focus on ZeroNet tab or window, zeronet.py process would be halted or resumed. 

This doesn't hurt the ZeroNet's data share spirit much isn't it? :)

> [trenta3](#comment_39_14mSHL2TBcqcLNcfpmg5jyGVS9RZia3FiX): Well, in this way you are sharing ZeroNet content only when you are looking at it. This has the exact same problem as before, it is only a little subtle: let's pretend you only watch ZeroNet tabs for about twenty minutes per day (I think it is an abundant estimate, given how much content ZeroNet currently has), so you only help spread other's messages twenty minutes per day. [...]

Good point. Thank u for ur kind explanation.
But actually I'm rather concerning about SDD wear-leveling while turning on the zeronet.py . 
What do u think about this?

> [trenta3](#comment_40_14mSHL2TBcqcLNcfpmg5jyGVS9RZia3FiX): Well, sending files to others obviously does not wears you SSD since it only needs to read files.On the other hand having content distributed in lots of little files, each one in its own folder, isn't very hard-drive friendly. On each update you have to rewrite the actual file containing data plus the content.json for that user, and then import such changes in the database file, so the hard disk does indeed some work. [...]

In case of (for example).../ZeroNet/data/16J4mEgR5aqerfzGy2WctNV3onPQUgF2E5/data/users/16dEowtNbV89NxPcDrAKkmnuXtiJVoVcDm/data.json , it is updating by removing the contents in the middle of the text file and adding new contents again in the middle of the text file. It means, to add a single character to the somewhere near top part of the text file, SDD has to erase the entire file from the block and write again. That is, unfortunately if a group of people is commenting or voting/unvoting to a certain post very frequently and unfortunately again you're the first peer receiving all those minor updates continuously (not like receiving the final update version after hundreds of changes), your SDD must suffer a lot. 

Regarding data.json, I'm thinking of continuous tailing structure rather than the current in-the-middle-updating structure. For the tailing structure, it would behave like the old read-only CD-ROM's continuous tail writing mechanism by flagging DELETE for the old files if the user wants to assume it's deleted or updated. Of course this is also like mbox structure. After a certain period of time or after reaching a certain size of mbox file, zeronet could prompt 'compact user.json?' or perform auto-compaction by itself. 

I don't know if mbox style doesn't compromise wear-leveling or not since basically in order to write anything to the SSD you have to first erase an entire block of SSD anyway. I think updating user.json with mbox or tailing style would not compromise by means of TRIM mechanism or something? This should be studied further anyway.

> [blurhy](#comment_176_1JcHMiQxXHX9q3ZK2LF9rZjvg3MUtTpcK): You can simply limit zeronet's cpu or network,or lower its process priority

It could suppress CPU% but will not affect SDD read/write and network traffic at all since disk rw and network transaction don't require much CPU resource. 

Actually you have to put the PID or CPU to sleep not just limit. 
Both can be done easily, (just ctrl-s. :) but finding how to get it done automatically is the matter of question.

> [james007](#comment_187_1DiRWRFXcVgQQ75cXnAG2pyxxjGo2VaH5): I've seen this happen before when Tor is left running for awhile. Solution is to clear the /var/lib/tor/data directory. 1545454147_19AR8ndYAaE6Q2yRAcpTKmkwtyJ5E.body: Different depending on which OS you're in. Windows or Linux?

If Windows, install and run tor-browser first and run zeronet with the following options: --tor always --tor_proxy localhost:9150 --tor_controller localhost:9151

If Linux, run $ sudo apt install tor; then, run zeronet with the following options: --tor always --tor_proxy localhost:9505 --tor_controller localhost:9051

Watch out that the numbers are different between windows and linux.

> [againandagain](#comment_1_189NY4UEquWaJSuXckuiGqDRpG77iJ7cAF): Is my reasoning not clear, or am I missing something here?

Regarding SSD, take advantage of its OUTPUT(read) performance from I/O, also known as INPUT/OUTPUT. But if it's not for something to do with time critical job u'd better not take advantage of its INPUT(write) performance since SSD wears off whenever INPUT access (writing to SSD) being triggered.

Smart determination to use INPUT performance in each case saves u of a lot of money from re-purchasing the pricy SSD in short intervals. :)

> [againandagain](#comment_2_189NY4UEquWaJSuXckuiGqDRpG77iJ7cAF): I have never had an SSD fail due to writing. If SSD should fail, it will do so in short time from purchase. I still have my first 60GB SSD, another set 2x128GB as cache running sometime a few TB/day of writes. Trust me, that small writes from web cache will not kill it. Keep your eye on media wearout and you will be fine.

(I also never had SSD failure till now :p. Neither did even with SD cards of mine)

SSD manufacturers know very well how you guys know about their products and they're reducing the lifespan of their products shorter and shorter and cheaper and cheaper by increasing multitudes of cells in a single bit of NAND flash memory. 

In the beginning they sold MLC (2 bits share a single physical bit of SSD) products, and they began to sell TLC (4 bits in a bit). Now they began to sell QLC (8bits). Someday they will proudly sell OLC. lol~. 
If more bits are sharing a single physical bit space, that bit will be accessed more often, that means early death.

Be prepared for their ripping off from now on. SAMSUNG is not your friend or servant. It is just a greedy thief staring at ur pocket 24/7.

> [againandagain](#comment_3_189NY4UEquWaJSuXckuiGqDRpG77iJ7cAF): writing to QLC directly can be as low as 50-70MB/s so worse than HDD

That's not such an easy math to determine the READ/WRITE speed of QLC. 
SSD itself has it's own MCU in it and by various software or hardware RAID tech such slowness can be overcome while costing power consumption or lifespan, etc. 

(Moreover, even the slowest SSD has a benefit over HDD such as shock-immunity and less power consumption, etc)

> [againandagain](#comment_3_189NY4UEquWaJSuXckuiGqDRpG77iJ7cAF): I only have one TLC SSD, 128GB after writing 2.5TB still has 98% of lifespan according to smart.

I didn't have this issue focused on ZeroNet specifically. 
Evidence tells. After I moved the mentioned burdens to RAM from SSD, decrement of my Wear_Leveling_Count value became very slow. Actually fixed at 95 for almost 1 year out of 4 or 5.
In nature, NAND flash memory is prone to huge amount of errors during the operation. They just seem to be hidden from the sight of the people by help of the MCU in it. That is, longevity of each SSD can be somewhat random.

> [kaffie](#comment_781_1NWh3WAty57FH8at1WtrZigMrdhrDkuPzh): I'm still failing to see why anything needs to be posted publicly for private mail.

If u post a PGP encrypted msg publicly, it can't be called publicly anymore since no one can read it. In this case, they even don't know who is the recipient either. If u want hide the sender too, just make another ID and post with that ID.
Moreover, if u post that encrypted msg in a private site, no one except the recipient knows on earth where and what is the msg.

This is just in order to workaround the capacity limit of zeromail while keeping using zeromail anyway.

FYI, PGP encryption, how it works: 
"every one has their own PRIVATE KEY & PUBLIC KEY pair. 
If u encrypt a msg with the recipient's PUBLIC KEY, no one can decrypt the msg except the paired PRIVATE KEY owner a.k.a. the recipient. Vise versa, if the recipient wants to reply the msg, he can simply encrypt the msg with your PUBLIC KEY and send it to u or just throw the msg on the road. Public key encrypted msg can be only decrypted by the paird PRIVATE KEY.
PRIVATE KEY should not be revealed to anyone except its owner, but PUBLIC KEY should be announced to as many people as possible in order to receive any msg from anybody in encrypted state."

> [pexo](#comment_58_1DfrA2M9Qra6stqT6tzwNMYNweswY54KAC): You try to look up json_id in the user table, this won't work.json_id is an automatically generated row by zeronet and links users and their content on each table together.json_id can be understood as a reference to the content.json of the user, that something else belongs to.ZeroNet generates the json table which contains all the corresponding values to the json_id reference, such as site(=hub), directory, file_name, cert_auth_type and so on.Doing: [...]

> [pexo](#comment_59_1DfrA2M9Qra6stqT6tzwNMYNweswY54KAC): Because ZeroNet also generates these references for the user table(in fact ZeroNet generates them for every table in every database). Since the json_ids are counted up, you'll find that especially the lower(so json_id=1 or 44 or 853 for example) ones will be on there by chance. They most likely won't point to the same user, though. The reason for that is how exactly ZeroNet generates these references.

As nodes of network increase in number, you will have more chances to bump into more users aka more data sources. I wish I was born in America or in Japan in regard with computer tech.
Of course nowadays it's meaningless anymore.

> [thebloomingmonk](#comment_4_159A9mgy8Rj1VR6hVoen597LKFZYuvU722): as someone who was born in the U.S, I have to say, its not all its cracked up to be (anymore).  Having been born at the end of the 90s, I grew up a fairly plain life.  Porn was my go to for tech since 2006.  Steady fast internet allowed for degeneracy.  Not, I wouldn't have wanted to be born in any other country, but just be thankful for where you are from.

When I was small My mom bought me a z-80 PC and I memorized the entire BASIC source code book.
I was known as a computer genius among teachers and kids since there's nothing I can't solve or make in the display.
I even made some action games but there's no way to understand why my games are so slow that they can't be compared with those of Japanese games for z-80 CPU. 
No ones were around me to guide. No tech books I could reach even though I went to the library and bookstore every week for shopping for the tech books.
But around 10 years later from that time at last I could realize that in Japan and USA they'd been already enjoying computer renaissance for more than 30 years with lots of magazines and forums with essence of the real mechanism of the PC, not dumb BASIC or impractical C languages without the knowledge of any hardware and Assembly language.
.
While you guys were tilling the farm, I was collecting wild strawberries in the wildness to fill the stomach. 
While u guys were reading books and eating preserved crops in the cozy hut in the cold winter, I had to be busy in hunting in the snow all day long. lol
.
In China Mencius said his mom changed the place of residence 3 times for his education.
In Korea we have a proverb saying once a man is born he has to move to Seoul, once a horse is born it has to move to Jaejudo to grow up in the best shape.

@mg0 @gitcenter **SOLVED.**

Running `./ZeroNet.sh in ZeroBundle/` works but `./ZeroNet.sh in ZeroBundle/ZeroNet/` doesn't.

Two files have a slight difference as follows: 

      <<ZeroBundle/ZeroNet.sh>>             |  <<ZeroBundle/ZeroNet/ZeroNet.sh>>
      #!/bin/bash                           |  #!/bin/bash
      cd "$(dirname "$0")"                  |  cd "$(dirname "$0")"
      if [ x$DISPLAY != x ] ; then          |  if [ x$DISPLAY != x ] ; then
          # Has gui, open browser           |      # Has gui, open browser
          # SCRIPT="start.py" # commented to|      SCRIPT="start.py"
          SCRIPT="zeronet.py" # replaced // |  ----------------------------------------
      else                                  |  else
          # No gui                          |      # No gui
          SCRIPT="zeronet.py"               |      SCRIPT="zeronet.py"
      fi                                    |  fi
                                            |
      if [ -d "ZeroNet" ]; then             |  if [ -d "ZeroNet" ]; then
    -     cd "$(dirname "$0")/ZeroNet"      |-     cd "$(dirname "$0")/ZeroNet"
    |     ../Python/python $SCRIPT "$@"     ||     ../Python/python $SCRIPT "$@"
    | else                                  || else
    |     ./Python/python -m zerobundle.run ||     ./Python/python -m zerobundle.run "h
    | fi                                    || fi

1546815090_1L4dZcDF2maSKHDy788yhxpYnBWnX.body:
I solved this by `$ sudo systemctl restart tor.service; sleep 3; sudo chmod g+rwx /var/lib/tor /var/lib/tor/control_auth_cookie; ./ZeroNet.sh`.

I don't know why, but after installing tor & torsocks on fresh Arch Linux tor.service seems to keep masking group permission. As a result In spite of my `usermod`ing my user id to the group id tor, ./ZeroNet.sh continuously showed error msg 'permission denied' regarding /var/lib/tor/control_auth_cookie.

So I found out that I had to manually set rwx on /var/lib/tor and /var/lib/tor/control_auth_cookie before running zeronet or after restarting tor.service.

Why this happens? I still don't know. @nofish

> [kusoneko](#comment_99_16PfVSZrUZuwTgs7wBt1t3ZK9rsvdskoe5): I usually start Zeronet with the following while in the tor group to prevent that error: $ sudo chmod 650 /var/lib/tor && sudo chmod 650 /var/lib/tor/control_auth_cookie && ./start.py, works every time.

Could u tell me why it has to be 650 rather than 640?

> [kusoneko](#comment_101_16PfVSZrUZuwTgs7wBt1t3ZK9rsvdskoe5): I'm not sure, actually. I'd try it but I'm not restarting zeronet anytime soon, and I've added the line below CookieAuthFileGroupReadable 1, so it shouldn't be required again, and even if it is, 5 is closer to 6, so my fingers are likely going to go there on their own by habit. Plus making the control_auth_cookie and tor folder executable doesn't actually matter much, since executing it won't do much as it's a cookie.

But as I remember, it should be executable in order not to have 'permission denied' error. But I still don't know why.

> [parsleycilantro](#comment_4_1NVmsWAF88eiamogSRiUzzSVKbsakUnn62): Basically, make sure the file is readable by the tor group and make sure your user account is part of the tor group. [...]

The problem is that the file and the folder containing the file becomes masked with the group permission whenever it restarts.
